title: Gala Bingo Clubs Sold As £241m Deal Confirmed
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 26, 2015, 10:16 GMT - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 14 mins Gala Bingo Clubs Sold As £241m Deal Confirmed By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 1 hour 7 minutes ago 

Britain's biggest bingo chain Gala has been sold in a £241m deal. 
Caledonia Investments confirmed the deal, first reported by Sky News, which will see it acquire the 130-strong chain of bingo clubs, with a market share of 38%, from Gala Coral. 
The British investment trust said Gala had 1.1 million active members and brought in pre-tax profits of £33m for the year to 26 September. 
Completion of the deal is subject to approval by the Gambling Commission. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) will result in a £155m debt facility plus Caledonia investing £97.8m to acquire a 99.5% stake in Gala, with a small chunk acquired by management. 
Duncan Johnson, Caledonia’s head of unquoted investments, said Gala’s business model was an ideal fit for its portfolio. 
Gala chief executive Simon Wykes said: "We are delighted to have secured Caledonia's backing in the next phase of Gala Bingo's development. 
"We believe that Caledonia’s longer term, supportive investment model will give Gala Bingo the stable platform from which we can continue to develop our market leading business." 
For Gala Coral, it paves the way for its £2bn merger with bookmaker Ladbrokes (Amsterdam: LB6.AS - news ) – subject to approval by competition regulators. 
Gala Coral said it would retain both the Gala brand and websites Galabingo.com and Galacasino.com. The bingo clubs will continue to trade under the Gala brand through a licence agreement. 
Gala Coral chief executive Carl Leaver said: "The sale is another transformative step for Gala Coral Group, following the turnaround of the business over the past few years." 
Caledonia traces its roots to the shipping empire established by Sir Charles Cayzer in 1878, and is now a listed investment trust which manages a portfolio of international quoted, unquoted and fund investments. 
It has one of the longest unbroken runs of dividend increases on the London stock market, and is understood to be attracted to the bingo business because of its reliable revenue streams. 
Caledonia’s largest unquoted holdings include Park Holidays, and Seven Investment Management, an asset manager. 
It also owns significant stakes in public companies such as AG Barr, the soft drinks manufacturer, and Close Brothers (LSE: CBG.L - news ) , the financial services group.
